loan_history: Cf. especially the vocalized forms: Serbian-Croatian ùnuk, Ukrainian dialectal onúk.
other_comments: The source form is a Hungarian dialectal form onoka (confirmed); cf. standard Hungarian unoka. The term is likely to be an insertion, as there is no lexicalized Early Romani term for ‘grandson’ or ‘grandchild’: analytic expressions ‘son/child’s son/child’ and ‘daughter’s son/child’ were used, as they still are in many Romani dialects.

borrowed_base: The word’s derivational base, the noun šógori ‘brother-in-law’, is a loanword (see LWT).
comment_on_borrowed: The word is derived from an Hungarian-origin noun by means of the Serbian-Croatian-origin suffix -kiň-.

other_comments:
calque: The lack of gender distinctions between ‘he’ and ‘she’ in the nominative is due to grammatical replication from Hungarian, where ő ‘he; she’. The gender-indifferent form ój reflects the Early Romani feminine form *oj ‘she’.
Unlike Hungarian, the two pronouns are distinguished in non-nominative cases, cf. l-es- ‘him’ vs. l-a- ‘her’.

borrowed_base: The derivational base of the adjective muslimko ‘Muslim’, the noun muslimo ‘Muslim’, is a loanword (see LWT); and the noun khangéri may be a loanword (see LWT).

other_comments:
loan basis: The word’s base muslim is a borrowed morpheme that corresponds to an independent nominal loanword (see LWT: muslimo); the word’s base khangéri may be a loanword (see LWT).
calque: The compound is a semi-calque of colloquial Hungarian muszlim+templom [Muslim+temple] ‘Muslim temple’, i.e. ‘mosque’.

comment_on_borrowed: Only the nominative form ništ(a) is borrowed. The oblique forms are derived from the indigenous interrogative so ‘what’ by means of the South Slavic-origin negative prefix ni-.

borrowed_base: The word’s root, *murd-, may be a loanword (see LWT: murdaren).
comment_on_borrowed: Although there is no Indo-Aryan etymology, Mānušs et al. (1997: 89) suggestion of the Persian origin of the word is unconvincing on phonetic and morphological grounds.

The Old Indo-Aryan etymology (Boretzky & Igla 1994: 112, Mānušs et al. 1997: 63) does not explain the initial Early Romani /x/. The Persian etymology, however, is even more problematic on phonetic grounds.
etymological_note: The Early Romani reconstruction *xanṛuv- ‘to scratch, to scrape’ assumes an OIA form *khaṇḍūyati, i.e. with an initial aspiration.
